debateSection.name: debate
debateSection.heading: General Scheme of the Apartment and Duplex Defects Remediation Bill 2024: Discussion (Resumed)

speech.p: I advise members of the constitutional requirement that they must be physically present within the confines of the Leinster House complex in order to participate in public meetings.

The general scheme of the department and duplex defects remediation scheme Bill proposes to make provision for the payment of grants for the remediation of fire safety, structure safety and water ingress defects in purpose-built apartment buildings, including duplexes, constructed between 1991 and 2013, and related matters. An interim remediation scheme for the funding of emergency fire safety defects works in apartments and duplexes is currently administered by the Housing Agency.

I am pleased that today we will have the opportunity to consider these and other related matters with representatives from the Department of Housing, Local Government and Heritage, the Housing Agency and Dublin Fire Brigade. From the Department, I welcome: Ms Caroline Timmons, assistant secretary; Mr. Derek Rafferty, principal officer; Mr. John Wickham, senior adviser; and Mr. Eoin O'Dowd, architectural engineer and inspector. From the Housing Agency, I welcome: Mr. Martin Whelan, CEO; Mr. Ronan O'Halloran; and Mr. Martin J. Hernon. From Dublin Fire Brigade, I welcome: Mr. Greg O'Dwyer, chief fire officer; and Ms Mary O'Brien, assistant chief fire officer.

Before we start, I wish to explain some limitations to parliamentary privilege and the practice of the Houses with regard to references witnesses may make to others in their evidence. The evidence of witnesses physically present or who give evidence from within the parliamentary precincts is protected pursuant to both the Constitution and statute by absolute privilege. Witnesses are reminded of the long-standing parliamentary practice that they should not criticise or make charges against any person or entity by name or in such a way as to make him, her or it identifiable or otherwise engage in speech that might be regarded as damaging to the good name of the person or entity. Therefore, if their statements are potentially defamatory in respect of an identifiable person or entity, they will be directed to discontinue their remarks. It is imperative that they comply with any such direction.

The opening statements have been circulated to members. With the short time available, we will take them as read. Is it agreed that they be published on the Oireachtas website? Agreed. We have a speaking rota. Members will have read the opening statements and will be very familiar with the scheme. I will start with Deputy McAuliffe.

Will ask Ms Timmons to take us through some of supports with regard to owners' management companies, OMCs? Perhaps that is the place to start. Concerns were expressed previously in relation to procurement, the availability of frameworks and so on. Perhaps Ms Timmons would talk to us about how the legislation will allow for that.

We have worked with the Housing Agency over the past while to build the legislation, based on the findings identified by means of the interim scheme. Some of the things that came through strongly included that there is complexity in the scheme. There are requirements for engagement with the local authority fire service and public procurement. It is quite an extensive process. What emerged during that interim scheme was that some of the OMCs have very good capacity. However, even those with good capacity have found it complex. Some OMCs have little to no capacity to engage with the scheme, even though the Housing Agency has provided an excellent advisory service. One of the particular findings that the Housing Agency has been putting to us, along with some of the stakeholders we meet, is that some project management assistance would be welcome in that regard. The Department is happy to consider that as part of the proposals as we move forward.
What format will that take? Will it be an online Zoom presentation to show how to do it or will it be more in the form of hands-on support?

We do not have a formal proposal yet, but the expectation, from talking to representatives of the Housing Agency and the stakeholders, is that we will appoint a specific person to each project to manage it properly, interact with the OMC and take the project from start to finish. This is hands-on.
That person will not take ultimate responsibility for the project; they will be there as a guiding assistant.
That seems necessary to ensure that this works. We will look at the proposal when it comes in, but that is the expectation of the content.

My follow-on question relates to a matter I previously raised with Ms Timmons. It is about the broader issue of OMCs and the regulation thereof. That is still a function of the Department of justice. I have spoken to both Ministers about the issue. Is there any further update in that regard?
The Deputy is aware of the legal issue that persists. The Department of justice has to make a change to the primary legislation before it can be transferred. I understand that is under way.
The expertise in that area lies in the Department of justice so it is better that it makes that-----
It has to. We are not allowed to make that primary change for the Department of justice. It must make it.
Is that happening? At what level is that conversation happening between the two Departments?

There have certainly been meetings at assistant secretary level. Our corporate side has talked to its corporate side. We have already had the transfer of the Property Services Regulatory Authority, which only occurred in August. Had everything been okay on the legal side, the transfer would have been intended to happen at the same time. Subject to the Mulcreevy issue with the Act being sorted out, it should not be too much longer. It is on the legislative agenda for the Department of justice.
I will come back in later rounds about pathfinders and things like that. The witnesses have the opportunity to see different levels of compliance.

In some apartments, it will be something routine or easy to be resolved, while in others it would be significant. Will the witnesses paint a picture of the scale of the different types of works that might be required in OMCs and the potential threat as a result?
Who is the question for?
It is for Dublin Fire Brigade.

There are a wide variety of deficiencies apparent in apartment buildings. They can range from minor to quite complex. The pathfinder experience has shown us that there can be quite complex deficiencies in these buildings.
Will Ms O'Brien provide us with some examples?

For example, fire stopping is an issue, as is the installation of fire doors. In some instances, hopefully rare, the build of the external walls may be an issue. That will be assessed on a case-by-case basis.
Would that be at the extreme end?
That would very much be at the extreme end.
At this stage, without having a full audit, Ms O'Brien has no idea of the prevalence of that kind of serious-----
That is exactly it. It is only as the risk assessments are carried out, the details are uncovered and the opening up works are done that the extent of the effects will be uncovered.
As we go forward, how will the expertise of Dublin Fire Brigade be folded into the OMC project process? At what stage is the Dublin Fire Brigade involved as we go through the project?

I am aware from the Housing Agency that there are a number of phases to the scheme. Dublin Fire Brigade is part of phase 3 or 4, although I stand to be corrected on that. At that stage, we engage with the competent professional who is appointed on behalf of the OMC. We ask that professional to send us a package of information, which includes as-built drawings, a fire safety assessment, a risk assessment, a full remediation plan and an interim remediation plan. Our level of engagement generally will be with the competent professional. I am heartened to hear that a project manager is being considered because that individual will certainly bring support to the competent professional and all the other individuals who may be tasked with helping with the production of the information. It is important that the competent professional work closely with the project management. That linkage will be important going forward.

I thank the witnesses for their presentations. The briefing document is exceptionally helpful. If that was not covered by the agreement we made at the start, it should also be published. It is a document of some public interest.

The first point that would be good for our committee to understand is that it is just under two years since the interim scheme opened. There have been 229 applications, which is equivalent to about 20,000 apartments. Four pathfinders were extracted from that early last year, but only one grant has been awarded, with three are still pending. Will the Housing Agency talk us through those two years? If we take the one pathfinder that has been approved, what were the steps and stages? For something that was meant to be an interim fire safety scheme that was meant to deal with urgent fire safety works, how can we understand why it has taken so long to get one grant award from that set of 229 applications? This is for us to understand that process.

Before my colleague comes in, I will give a quick update. The Deputy is right. When we took on the scheme, there was no set of set instructions or toolkit in place. We have had significant learnings. We also now have considerable hindsight, which can help inform the statutory scheme and, more important in the here and now, will help us deliver on the interim scheme.

On the numbers, we have validated 229 applications relating to some 20,000 apartments. That is the immediate pipeline for projects that will go into construction next year and beyond. Of those, 44 are in a position to enter our dynamic purchasing system, DPS. That is a procurement framework for the appointment of the competent professionals my colleague referred to. That pipeline is ready to go. It is advanced.

On the four pathfinders, the first, largest and most complicated is Crescent Park in Park West. It has grant agreement and construction has begun, which is a positive. Two further projects - Seabrook Manor in Portmarnock and Wellington Court on Mountjoy Street - are at phase 4. That means they have submitted the relevant documentation to enable my colleagues to carry out the various assessments. We expect to be able to move to grant agreement within the coming weeks, hopefully before Christmas. On the fourth project, Chambers Park in Kilcock, County Kildare, the OMC confirmed that it did not and could not furnish proof of ownership of the common areas. For this reason, under the scheme as currently constituted, it could not progress. We have just received welcome confirmation from our colleagues in the Department that the legal requirement is no longer a provision of the scheme. We have engaged with the OMC today. It is at an advanced stage. I think it has tendered for building works, so that pathfinder will move quickly. I totally accept that there has been a two-year period, but we are now beginning to see the fruits and benefits of the work and learnings that have gone into that.

There are two key requirements for us. The first is dedicated, professional project management to work hand in glove with OMCs to guide them through every stage of the process. That is critically important. Alongside that, we need accessible, robust and transparent frameworks for the procurement of both the consultants - the competent professionals - and builders. We have the first in place. We are going through the final stages of back-and-forth with the applicants. That will come on stream shortly. We are now looking at the best possible mechanism to stand up the framework for the procurement of builders to complete the work.

Before Mr. Whelan brings in his colleague, on those 44 applications that are in a position to move towards the competent professionals, is the expectation that they will start to progress their way through the scheme in parallel with the passage of the primary legislation to deal with the wider defects scheme? Before that scheme is open to applications, does the Housing Agency expect a significant number of those 44 applications to be at a more advanced stage?

Absolutely. We feel that 20 are ready to go. The documentation is in place. There is a phased nature to this as well to accommodate our colleagues in the local authority, fire services and capacity. There are 24 schemes immediately behind those 20 which will be in place to follow. As far as we concerned, the interim scheme proceeds as planned in the here and now, including the DPS and the other measures we have talked about. That is the lesson. It is to support OMCs through those mechanisms to get to the position we all want to get to, that is, where we are now, thankfully, with Park West in terms of the commencement of the remediation that is envisaged by the Oireachtas.
I am out of time. I will come back to Mr. O'Halloran in the second round.

The big concern of mine, which was raised at the previous committee meeting, is the risk to life and health and the risk of harm to the people in buildings. That is what I have been particularly concerned about and that the buildings are remediated on an emergency basis as soon as possible. What is the fire service's assessment of the current risk to life and to the safety of buildings? I ask the other witnesses how that is being addressed now and how it will be addressed in the coming months.
We all want people to be safe in their homes and every building. How is that categorised and how is safety measured? That is not an easy thing to do. There is no such thing as zero risk.

We can have risk mitigation measures. In the context of fire safety in buildings, we have layers of risk mitigation measures. That is how we would approach fire safety in buildings to try to reduce risk and increase safety. We know there may be defects in these buildings. That would be uncovered because the risk assessments are done, as I mentioned earlier. There are things people can do to keep themselves safe. The legislation is framed such that the persons in control of a building have responsibility for fire safety.

I understand that. When we visited the apartment block in question recently, we saw that there is mitigation. Some people are hiring security and all sorts. From the Fire Brigade's perspective, are there buildings that are currently classed as high risk?

For any building that we are aware of that is of high risk, we have significant enforcement powers under the Fire Services Act, and we act on those powers as judiciously as possible while being aware that these are people's homes we are talking about. In every case, we engage with the OMC or the persons in control of the building to try to mitigate the risk to a sufficient level that they may stay in their homes until deficiencies that are uncovered can be-----
Is the Fire Brigade concerned?

All the buildings we are talking about in the scope of the scheme have fire safety certificates. That means they have a general level of safety in compliance with the minimum standard of the building regulations. Invariably these buildings are built of non-combustible materials. All of these buildings have protected escape routes. While they may not be 100% because of deficiencies in the building the overall picture is that they are robust buildings. There are things that can be done for mitigation and the Deputy saw that in the building he visited.

In addition, for any of the premises we know are at risk we have carried out significant pre-incident plans for those buildings. We have tagged our mobilisation system. If we get an incident in one of those buildings, there is a tag that informs the responding officers that they are going to a building that may not act in the way they think it should. They also have the pre-incident plan to refer to.
Are there not buildings the Fire Brigade has not had access to and has not assessed?
There are buildings we do not know of yet.
Yes, apartment blocks and apartment complexes.
Yes. Some of those buildings would probably pre-incident plans on them even though they may not have been identified as defective premises yet.
We cannot really say that all the apartment blocks affected by defective issues are not at a high risk.
We do not know yet.
No, we do not know.
The scheme is demand led so we will not know until people-----

I understand that in terms of the scheme. I do not know how to describe this. There are ones applying for the scheme. However, in general does Dublin Fire Brigade carry out assessments of apartment blocks that are potentially dangerous, or does it only operate on the basis of someone contacting it?
In an ideal world, we would love to be able to do that, but in terms of capacity we deal with what comes towards us and advise as such.
I asked this on the previous occasion. Is the Department concerned that there are potentially buildings we do not know about that are at high risk, particularly from defects around fire?

As Ms O'Brien has pointed out it is an unknown quantum in the context of the built environment. There are many buildings. We expect there are robust laws in place in terms of building control and building regulations. The Fire Services Acts are engineered and geared towards ensuring those levels of safety. Where they are an unknown quantum it is a demand-led system. Where applications come through to the process there are robust procedures in place to determine the level of non-conformity and utilise the procedures. However, the built environment is an unknown quantum.
Is the Department worried about that?

Our regulations are quite strong. I do not think we are having an indication that there is a concern we need to address immediately. If one was brought to our attention, the Deputy can be assured that we would absolutely act on it.

It is concerning that we are not pre-emptively assessing. We are probably aware that there are apartment blocks affected by defects that are probably high risk that we do not know about because people are not partaking in the scheme or do not have the owner management system set up. Is there something we can do to address that?

It has certainly been put that the owner management company system needs to be strengthened. It is something the Department will reviewing next year. As the Deputy is aware, one of the actions in the new housing plan is that we undertake a review of the Act once it comes over to us. OMCs need to be strengthened in that regard, particularly where they are responsible for fire safety in their buildings. That is a fair point.

I thank the witnesses for being here. I will start with the interim remediation scheme. They have outlined 229 applications in approximately two years. Do we anticipate further applications at this stage?

-----all the while there are references to OMCs and multi-unit developments. We have a unit in the Department that engages with OMCs around the country in a different context. We engage on that and bring information about this scheme to the attention of those groupings.
At the Housing Agency we have an outreach campaign that speaks to the previous question.
Deputy Hearne's question, yes.

We have external facing communications. We have the website. We have gov.ie. We have our multi-unit developments, MUDs, road show that travels around the country. We have added slides into that, which refer to the interim scheme, how to apply to it and the premise of the scheme. As the interim scheme begins to show progress going forward it will draw other OMCs to apply to it.

I am trying to get an understanding of the scale. Overall, we are saying there are 100,000 apartments that will need remediation work, but we are only at 20,000 with the remediation scheme. It goes to Deputy Hearne's point. There are potentially residents out there in apartment blocks where there are not organised OMCs where they are effectively brushing this under the carpet because nobody is stepping up to lead an OMC.

I go back to the figure of 100,000 homes that was spoken about. That is derived from the 2022 working group report, which I am sure everyone is familiar with. Within that 100,000 there is a breakdown that to our knowledge there are approximately 44,000 homes that have not been remediated. The remainder either have been remediated or are currently undergoing remediation works outside of the scheme we are speaking about.
Sorry, so 44,000 have not.
There are 44,000 completely outstanding. We have applications in for in excess of 20,000.
That is just under half of those.
We hope, as our delivery pipeline increases moving into 2026 that we will get closer to that 44,000 figure. That would be the intention.
The interim scheme effectively will capture the majority of outstanding-----
Of interim houses. That is correct. We will not capture the water ingress or structural defects.
I understand that. The interim scheme is obviously for the immediate safety concerns. There will be a significant number of applications to come yet. That is their anticipation.
We think so, yes.
I will focus on the Housing Agency for now. It referred to learnings from the process as it has evolved and so on. The common area issue is resolved now as I understand it.

That is a significant development. We and our colleagues in the Department were aware of the fact that precluded a significant proportion of potential applicants, and we had a number of potential projects stalled. The advisory from the Department on that is very significant.
That should speed up.
That would not only speed up, but that would also bring into play a number of developments where substantial preparatory work-----
But they were stalled.
-----has been done so we are not starting from standing still. That is a significant development.
The other key item in the opening statement related to project management. Have we agreement on that now?

We are preparing a detailed proposal, which we will submit to our colleagues in the Department. The Department has been supportive of our position on this and understanding of where we are coming from. The onus is on us, and we are advanced on the work in this area in making that proposal to our colleagues.

I will turn to the Department on that point about project management. Is there a willingness and acceptance to take that point and accept those recommendations, albeit it has not seen the report at this point? Is there an openness to that?
We will have to confirm. It is subject to the detailed proposal but the Minister has indicated that we should be open to the project management.
That is good. That was one of the points that was strongly made.

I will turn to the fire service, Dublin Fire Brigade and the issue of those areas most at risk. It was stated that a lot of planning work and pre-incident plans have been done. Obviously, not all these departments are in Dublin, so can we say the same of other fire services across the country? Does anyone want to take that question?

All fire services around the country have a national guidance document from the national directorate for fire and emergency management on pre-incident planning. They all apply the same methodology when looking at high-risk premises. It is a prioritisation system. Each local authority's fire service views the risks in its area and carries out an area risk categorisation. Any buildings, particularly high-rise apartment blocks, come in under that. A pre-incident plan would be carried out.

What I getting at concerns the 229 applications that are in. Are we sure there is proper co-ordination between all the fire services relating to those applications at a local level? Is there the same level of preparation and awareness as there is in Dublin Fire Brigade?

One of our work programmes over the last two years, to that very point, has been engagement with our local authority fire services colleagues. We have systematic engagement in place around that. As our colleagues pointed out, we have a number of stages in our application process. Some of those relate specifically to our engagement with our fire services colleagues. That is very joined-up.
Okay. That is good.
We are confident that engagement is positive and will yield the sort of structured phased delivery we require.
That is active. That is good to hear.

The committee carried out a site visit to Clarion Quay. One of the key points raised with us that day was the high costs for residents, particularly for insurance, because there are issues around safety and so on, which we are well aware of. In that case, if I am allowed to say this, there were annual charges of up to €8,000 per resident, which is a staggering amount of money. A significant part of that was the insurance cost. Is there any proposal to assist residents in the short term in covering those annual charges that are incurred directly as a result of these defects? It is something that badly needs to be looked at. It is not sustainable that residents have to pay that level of annual costs simply to live where they bought apartments. Specifically on the issue of insurance, and this is directed at the Department, is that something that could be considered, or has been considered or looked at?

The general issue has come up. As I understand it, the former Minister, Deputy Darragh O'Brien, met Insurance Ireland at the time, engaged with it on this and received assurances from the sector, at that point, in relation to its approach to the insurance of these particular developments. I am not sure we have detail to say that we absolutely need to do something about this or that we have any more detailed proposal; we have not. That is as far as it went in terms of the contact with Insurance Ireland. We have relied on those assurances.

I appreciate that. My time is up, but this point deserves further discussion. Whatever level of assurance was given to the former Minister at the time, that did not bear out in the discussions we had with the residents on their insurance costs. Perhaps it can be picked up.

I thank the witnesses for being here. In the last few weeks, when we discussed the various defects and the new Bill, etc., we brought up the example of Clarion Quay, where the fire spread in under 30 minutes. We also mentioned a housing development close to where I live in Newbridge, Millfield Manor, where six houses burnt down in under an hour. I know one of the residents there. The residents are taxpayers, yet it was their taxes that paid for the rebuilding of the houses and the fixes for defects. From the Department's statement, it seems the system is still being built and, after two years, people are wondering who built, designed and certified these buildings, and who inspected and insured them. Again, the people who did all of that are let off the hook and the people living in the houses, who are paying their taxes, are the ones who are paying for everything. It is the taxpayer once again. Do the witnesses feel, going forward, this will be something we will be able to deal with through this Bill?

It is not dealt with in this Bill. It is not part of what we have been asked to do. We have been asked to build a statutory scheme to provide grant assistance to people in these apartment buildings. That is not one of the issues countenanced in it.

A sum of €2.5 billion will be spent fixing a problem. Going forward, will we have another housing committee in two or years' time dealing with the same, and having to remediate issues that have happened in the last couple of years?

No. There has been significant change in respect of the regulations we have brought in over the intervening period, particularly from 2014 onwards. I will ask the expert colleagues I have brought with me to comment on some of the changes we have made that should provide some reassurance to the committee.

To go back to the original point about the cause and nature of the defects, I will bring it back to the report of the working group to examine defects in housing. It identified that there was no single cause of the failure. It was a multiplicity, including design, product and workmanship, as well as oversight, which formed part of it. There was no one single issue that caused a lot of these defects. The learning is we are living in the shadow of the legacy of defects in buildings. A lot of reforms have been initiated since 2014, primarily starting with the building control amendment regulations, which empowered professionalism and have brought a mandatory level of statutory certification of buildings and mandatory inspection. It first starts with getting the design of these buildings right, getting a certified design, getting it lodged with an inspection plan that is implemented throughout the course of the works on-site, and ending with a statutory certificate co-signed by a builder and competent professional.

We had all that before. We had the certification, the insurance and HomeBond, or whatever it was, but when we came calling for the money, it was not there. What changes have been put in place so that will not happen again?

Prior to 2014, what existed was an opinion of compliance by professionals that did not have a process of lodgement, of drawings in particular, with the building control. People who were registered professionals did their design. Builders built in accordance. They should have built in accordance with those designs-----
Will this new Bill fix all this, so we cannot repeat what has been done? I want to ask the fire brigade a question.
This new system has restored an accountability across the-----
Is that legally tight?

-----construction industry. That is legally tight. At the end of the day, it has borne fruit in terms of the quality of build that has happened since 2014. Colleagues in the local authorities may be able to clarify that.

Thanks for that. I will ask the fire brigade a question. Maybe two weeks ago, we had witnesses in here. They mentioned they have people who work - they had a word for them - basically as security personnel who look after fire safety. They mentioned the Beacon area. Their job is to be on-site 24 hours a day, seven days a week, to keep an eye out to see if fires break out, which seems very piecemeal. From the fire brigade point of view, lives can be protected with alarms, detection and clear escape routes.
Is there something questionable about that approach? Is it fixing a patch by applying a sticking plaster?

In some instances where defects are uncovered, interim measures are put in place to allow time and space for the defects to be fixed. In those instances, if there are defects in the fire detection alarm system itself or there is no fire detection alarm system, fire wardens, which were alluded to by the Senator, may be put in place for a temporary and short period because they are a very expensive solution to that problem. Obviously, we want to see the fire detection alarm system to be up and running in a building, especially in an apartment building, because it is a person's first line of defence, and that is what we would advise. We have accepted and advised the use of fire marshals in the past, as have other local authorities, but for a very short period. That is generally how they are used.
I call Deputy Ó Broin.
I am happy to cede to Fine Gael and I will come back in after.
Next is Deputy Paula Butterly.
My first question is on the proposal for project managers made by the Housing Agency. How soon will the agency be able to get that to the Department?
In days, Deputy. We are very advanced in our design of that. I would imagine that it will be days.
Yes.
So, before Christmas.
Absolutely.
How soon can the departmental officials assess the proposal and make a decision?

I cannot put a timeline on it but it will be quick. We are as anxious as anybody else to move this along. There is no particular reason to delay but it will depend on being able to move it to the Minister by Christmas, which we will have done ourselves. We will certainly have moved it that far.
Nobody has a crystal ball but I would imagine Ms Timmons has a good understanding as to the flavour of what will be contained in the proposal. Do we have a guarantee that it will receive priority?
It will receive priority, yes.
I thank Ms Timmons.

I thank the members of the Dublin Fire Brigade for coming in today. I noted Ms O'Brien said the scheme would be demand led, which will pose problems and challenges in regards to resources. How does the DFB suggest we could overcome the resources issue? It was also noted that the greater Dublin area would be particularly challenging. Perhaps the witnesses have already answered my questions, so I apologise for getting them to repeat their answers, but I would like to hear their views. Is the issue skill shortages or a lack of bodies? Pardon me, as that is a terrible way of putting it, but the witnesses know what I mean. "Boots on the ground" may be better terminology.

The scheme will be demand led. We know in advance that the vast majority of the homes will be in the Dublin region. For that reason, the local authority made an approach to the Department very early in the process seeking extra resources, and as part of that, we were granted a number of resources in the Dublin region. We have tried to recruit these resources for the last year but, unfortunately, have ran into significant difficulties. There literally is an insufficient number of boots on the ground, as the Deputy put it. It is not just our issue. Right across the local authorities and the wider public sector, it is a challenge to attract people. It is a huge challenge to attract the skills and experience needed for the scheme. We do not seem to be in a position to compete with the market. That is just a fact of life. We have been unable to recruit the number of staff for which we received sanction.
Is that from an economic perspective due to the salary offered? Is it due to the lifestyle, shift work or hours of work? What are the key barriers?

The main barrier is economic. We offer a very attractive workspace. We have normal office hours that is no shift work. We also have a balanced, family-friendly workspace. The main barriers are economic factors ,which is where we just cannot compete.

I have a few questions for the departmental officials. Considering these challenges and the key component that is required by the fire services in order for this scheme to work, will the Department review the pay conditions and salaries to attract more people into the fire services? This has been a challenge for the fire services over the last couple of years. I would not like to think this could be a stumbling block. Please pardon my use of bad terminology today, but it would be a major stumbling block if we cannot attract a key component into the scheme like the fire services.
To confirm what we said earlier, we have provided sanction for significant resources to the fire service. That was forthcoming very early on.

While I under the problems with recruitment, I am afraid that is not an area of my responsibility in the Department so I will take it back to the Department and acknowledge to my colleagues in that area that this issue has been raised at this committee meeting.

I guess that, at the beginning, the Department imagined that it would attract X amount of people at an Y salary base. That is not the case, so this issue is definitely something that requires urgent review.
I will take that back to the Department.
I thank Ms Timmons.

On the practical side, we have an agreement in place with the local authority fire services around the phasing and sequencing of proposals on a rolling four-to-six-week basis to take into consideration any capacity issues that may exist. That is well thought out and linked to known risk factors. I am not speaking to the resource issue but there is co-ordination as part of this project, which acknowledges the capacity issues that exist.
At a national level.
Absolutely. Across the country.
I thank the delegations for all of their answers because they are very helpful for informing the committee. I have some final questions.
It would be good for the committee if Mr. O'Halloran took us through the steps and explain, for the next group that comes through, how those steps will be shorter steps than is currently the case.

We are talking about the interim scheme but it will ultimately be rolled through the transitional mechanisms into the new scheme. I ask Ms Timmons to give us more information about how that is envisaged and the timeline because Mr. Whelan spoke about 44 additional schemes in a position to move into the dynamic purchasing system. Maybe there are 20 of those ready to go, but there is still an awful lot behind those. At what point will the interim scheme blend into the overall scheme? What is the thinking on that?

I have a final question for Ms Timmons and Mr. Whelan. Two of the other resourcing asks that arose in our conversations with others are as follows. One is the need for a tenant liaison to assist the OMCs and the approved housing body, AHB, sector to engage with tenants, particularly with large multi-unit developments, on all aspects of the organisation and mobilisation of the scheme. This is something very different from project management. Is this on the Department and Housing Agency's radars? Are they thinking about it? Do they think it has merit?

We met one of the large OMCs on site that has been through a partial remediation of its own block as a result of a fire but also has defects, probably to the value of €200,000 per apartment, and is currently paying management fees of €8,000 a year because a fire warden and very high-interest costs are included. The OMC's members also talked about the need for a client representative because their thinking was that project managers were just project management and an OMC board may not include people who understand contract law, for example, or other areas of responsibility. I am referring to somebody who is able to advise the OMC on those. That could be a set of services that the Housing Agency advises on or a stand-alone individual. I would like to hear a response to the two suggestions of a tenant liaison and client representative. I suggest Mr. O'Halloran will first outline the process and explain how it can be sped up with the learnings that he has outlined.

I thank the Deputy for that key question. It is an eight-phase process. I will not labour through the eight phases but they essentially are as follows. In phase 1, the application is received and validated by ourselves. The real work starts in phase 2, which is when an OMC has engaged a competent professional. The key pieces of work and the key documents that competent professional produces are the fire safety assessment, the fire safety risk assessment and, out of that, the remedial works plan. At that point, the OMC's competent professional then engages with our colleagues in the local authority fire services.
That is a key interaction in the overall process.

Regarding the pathfinders, we have spoken about the two years that has lapsed. I would like to speak to the work that has gone on in those two years and how we have fed those lessons learned back into our process going forward. In the example of when the remedial works plan is being drawn up, with the pathfinders, there are significant opening-up works to be done within the apartment block, as was mentioned earlier, to see what is in the walls, in the ceilings, what are the issues and the defects and to identify them. In the pathfinders, we found at times the works were not extensive enough and did not go far enough to determine and get enough information from the local authority fire services to provide sufficient comment to justify the progression of that OMC. On that basis, we have fed that back into our processes and now, at phase 3, the competent professional will be procured through a dynamic purchasing system. Again, it is a procurement mechanism, but it ensures a higher level of quality and a more detailed scope of works that the competent professional has to undertake when engaged by the OMC with our assistance. That means when the competent professional brings the remedial works plan to the local authority fire services the opening-up works will be more extensive and more categorical in determining where the defects are and what the level of defects are in the building and the nature of them. As a result, the remedial works plan will identify the measures absolutely required to remediate that. We are hoping it will help expedite the process while also bringing quality, supporting the OMCs further and bringing further comfort to the residents in those homes. As the phases progress and we pass into phase 4, we draft the grant agreement. Again, we have lessons learned from that to turn that around as quickly as possible. When the information hits the desk of the Housing Agency we work on that straight away. We will be able to get grant agreements back in a short number of weeks with the assistance of our colleagues in the Department.

I would like to go back to phase 3. My understanding is that in part one of the things that caused some of the delay with the pathfinders was not just the issues around the extent of the opening up and the assessment, but also reaching an agreement in principle between the competent professional and the OMC on one side and the fire service on the other because, ultimately the fire services have to be agreeable to the works that are going to be proposed for the scheduling in phase 4. Has there been sufficient learning from that so we will get a clear understanding of the that will be bar required by fire services for them to be able to sign off on the works programme?

There has, yes. We need to determine what the eligible works are under the scheme, what are defects-related and, for example, what are related to a lack of maintenance and issues like that. The pathfinders have been absolutely instrumental and the work that has gone into them in the past 18 months to two years. The findings related to quality in and quality out. That is across the board with the pathfinders and the engagement with the local authority fire services. There are a number of working groups which we participate in and this has all been discussed and reviewed and fed back through feedback loops. We are seeing the benefits of it now. Moving forward into next year, as the next OMCs progress through the system, we hope the process will become more efficient. We will be constantly reviewing the process and refining it and improving it all the time. It will also speak to the resource issues in the local authority fire services that the documents that will be hitting their desks will be more detailed and will have more pertinent information in them. There may not be as much requirement for back and forth to request further information. The intention is that the quality will be there from day one. The pathfinders and the work to date are absolutely instrumental in getting to that point.

The intention is to try to be as seamless as possible with the transitional arrangements under the scheme. Obviously, we are still building it but at the moment if an application has been made to the Housing Agency before the Act came in and the agency has not has not made a decision, it will be deemed to be brought in under the section of the Act and will be grandfathered straight in. If it has already made a decision on the application, that will be deemed to stand under the previous scheme. I do not think anyone will feel a particular change. Most people will move into the statutory-----

In those cases of those schemes, for people to avail of remediation of structural defects rather than fire safety, will they have to apply separately to the new scheme or will there be some other mechanism for them to be incorporated but for those wider structural defects to be assessed? Let us say they have water ingress and they are already at grant-awarding stage and contracting stage for their fire safety works, how do we get them into the structural for water ingress under the new scheme?

That would probably a matter for pragmatic management by the Housing Agency of the ones they are already aware of. If the details are already available to agency, there is no reason it cannot be dealt with from a practical perspective. However, they will need to make the application under the Act for those particular defects.
To the new scheme.

Yes, to the new scheme, because they are not in the old one. They will all have to be assessed because there will be documentation that will not be available in relation to those. It will have to be managed in a pragmatic sense. I do not see anybody trying to hold up applications unnecessarily. One of the issues that stakeholders have raised with us is that it is important the transition into the statutory scheme does not prevent us from taking care of the interim works that need to be done. We are very conscious that the scheme needs to operate in a way that even if an application is under the statutory scheme it does not mean they do not do interim works. They should still be able to do that. There should not be any difficulty there.
Quickly, on the tenant liaison and client representative-----
The Deputy has gone way over time. I call Deputy McGrath.

We are repeating similar points. Regarding what has evolved with the interim scheme, if an application is made today what is the approximate turnaround time the witnesses anticipate? In terms of the learnings and how the scheme has evolved, how do they see that going regarding a timeline?

We have data from the pathfinders. There is no doubt that has been a long process. It has been laborious and intensive for all the stakeholders involved. We have worked with the OMCs throughout the process. The timelines there could range from 12 to 18 months to get to a grant agreement to get to site. I hope with the lessons learned and the experiences to date we are feeding back into the system; which includes the project management work, the dynamic purchasing system and potential future frameworks for contractors, that we can expedite that process. We have to remember these are still significant projects in the realm of millions of euros.
Can we halve that timeframe?

Our focus is taking time out of the application process. Sometimes the delay and time are conflated. It will take a certain period in terms of construction and what we have worked on; the dynamic purchasing system, the procurement framework for builders; the project management. It is about taking as much time out of that as possible. I will build key performance indicators around that, so we have very transparent timelines. I believe we can take significant time out or the process, the applications-----
Yes, but obviously work still takes time.

That is the reality of it. These are significant. One of the projects we are just about to sign off on is a very complex, large-scale project that reflects the earlier comments on scale. That leads back to Deputy Ó Broin's comment. The project management and the term is my fault. I am talking about a very detailed construction professional support that will help fulfil the client relationship piece as well, as I will propose to the Department.
What is the budget for interim scheme for 2026?
The budgets have not been published yet. They will be published in the Revised Estimates. We do have a significant allocation in 2026 and will be more than enough to cover the scheme.
What will it be approximately?
It will be €100 million or so. I cannot confirm the exact amount.
It will be in that region. As the main scheme comes on track, the interim scheme will remain a live option. Will that remain the case for some time?

The interim scheme will be folded immediately into the statutory scheme, but the types of works that were available under the interim scheme will now be available under the statutory scheme. That is the intention.
Can the works that are necessary from a safety point of view be done upfront and then other works-----
That is the intention. The flexibility needs to be there to allow the scheme to move quickly.
The interim scheme, therefore, changes name but in effect it is the same approach.
That is the idea. It is just a difference in language of how we approach it, but it is the same idea.
I will just turn to the framework. Where exactly are we with professionals and builders at present?
The dynamic purchasing system has gone to the market and we are now dealing with queries from potential service providers who have applied to be part of that framework.

That is the normal procurement - answering queries, questions and so on. An important feature of that is it will remain live so parties can come into the process. As the pipeline of projects increases, we have the capacity to bring competent professionals on board. That is for professionals. We are looking at the option of a framework for builders, perhaps existing frameworks or we can do DPS, whichever is the most expedient. Both will be stood up.
There is no form of vetting taking place, necessarily.

We have certain provisions built in in terms of quality and standards. If someone has been involved in a scheme previously as a consultant, builder or contractor, they are excluded from working on that scheme. Quality control is built in. A lot of the checks we are now carrying out in relation to tenders are about standing up that-----
There can be a degree of confidence in the quality of-----
Absolutely.
There is some due diligence.

For competent professionals, we have wrapped criteria around that role. We experienced that it was variable in terms of competent professionals and their knowledge of the procurement process, etc. We have sought to shore that up by building it into the criteria.
When is it hoped that framework will be available in both cases?
Before Christmas.
Is that for the professionals and builders?
For the professionals, before Christmas. We are looking at it for builders now actively.
Will that take months?
We will have it stood up in time to meet the demand of projects that will result from the work of competent professionals.

There will be no delay. Once the competent professionals are engaged and the work my colleague outlined at phases 2 and 3 has been completed, our undertaking is to have the framework in place for builders. There will be no delay.

My next question is for the Department. For works already done and the retrospective reimbursement, if I understand correctly, that will not happen until the main scheme is up and running. Is that correct?

There is a report that needs to be brought to Government. The Housing Agency provided us with a report and we brought it to the Minister. We intend to finalise any thinking on retrospection, subject to anything in the report.
Will Ms Timmons give us a sense of the scale of the reimbursement that may be required for works already done?
I do not think I have any detail with me on the scale of that today. I can see what we have for the Deputy but there is a significant number of apartments which have already undergone works.
We are talking tens of thousands of apartments so it is obviously a significant amount of money.
Yes. There is a significant amount.
Ms Timmons does not have a figure on that.
No. I do not have a figure today.
Can we get that figure furnished to the committee once it is available?
Once it is available, absolutely.
Is it fair to say that when the main scheme is up and running, there will be a tsunami of applications for reimbursement based on works that are done? They will come in pretty quickly, I imagine.
We expect that funding will need to go out pretty quickly as works commence. We have a vast number of projects ready to go.
Is the Department preparing for that in the budgetary process to ensure the funding will be available to reimburse for works done?
Yes, there is no difficulty in that respect. That has all been smoothed out over the process of building the scheme. I do not anticipate any issues.
Of the overall bill of €2 billion or €2.5 billion, a significant part will be that reimbursement.
The retrospection could be significant but that depends on the decisions made in due course.
A large part of the overall bill will come quite quickly.
There is potential for that but there will be a process.

I have a couple of questions before I let Deputy Hearne in again. Following on from what Deputy McGrath said, Ms Timmons indicated that potentially €100 million would be available in 2026. If there is a tsunami of applicants, only €100 million is allocated.

I assure the Chair that if we have to revisit that, it is the first thing we would do. It is a demand-led scheme. The Department is not unaware of the potential for that. We probably have made sufficient provision for next year. When we were thinking about this, we did some calculations but, that said, if things change, we will be quick to respond.
The Department will be before the committee with further Estimates.
I hope we will not have to do that but that sometimes happens.
Following on from a meeting we had on the issue of the common areas, I think Mr. Whelan said there is a solution for a large number of those. Will anyone miss out?

We have estimated, based on the applications we received, that around 25% to 30% of OMCs are affected by this. It is an ongoing issue. The cost of remediation for OMCs is very onerous. We think the figure is higher because some of the OMCs that have not yet made applications are probably even more affected and are at an earlier stage. This decision brings all of those OMCs into place. It does not deal with the other issues we are trying to deal with and which we spoke about, but it means, all of a sudden, a large cohort of developments is now in play that could not apply under the scheme, as of today. This is a message we will send out from the Housing Agency to OMCs. As of today, all of those OMCs and developments are now eligible under the scheme we are operating. That is very welcome.
All of them are eligible. It is not the case that some will fall through the cracks and will not be eligible under the proposal.
No.
The Housing Agency is happy to say all of them will be eligible.
Yes, on that point. On the legal ownership point, the clarity we received from the Department is clear.

Ms Timmons mentioned project management. We met an OMC which was lucky enough to have a sufficient number of professionals living in the apartment complexes who were able to do a significant amount of work on what was not their fault, ultimately. Not everyone is in that position. Putting something in place to help them was mentioned. Will financial supports for those organisations or OMCs be in place to get legal or engineering advice, or whatever advice or professional supports they may need, to go through that process to be compensated for those costs and not be out of pocket for having to get professional help to proceed with the scheme?

I have not seen the proposal yet so I cannot comment on what would be covered. I do not know that all of the categories the Cathaoirleach mentioned will be covered, but the intention is there will be project managers of a calibre to give that advice to the OMC. Subject to seeing the proposal, I can inform the Cathaoirleach further as to what we agree in due course.

It is very important that no owner management company is out of pocket. They already are - Deputy Séamus McGrath and Deputy Ó Broin mentioned a figure of €8,000 in charges, as matters stand. They should not then start footing legal or professional bills to remedy something in their apartments that is not their fault. There have to be guarantees.
I should clarify that nobody has made any proposal about legal advice or legal professional fees. What is in play is project management fees. That is what we have been talking about.

It is to guide OMCs through the process. We envisage the calibre of the project management will be such that they will be knowledgeable and be able to assist. As the process becomes more streamlined, there should not be a requirement for additional or ancillary advice. We are talking about hand-holding during the process, a readily accessible framework to engage a competent professionals who then take on a significant degree of work and then to take on a competent builder. The proposal we will make will be as comprehensive as possible. When the details are seen, I will be happy to discuss it further. It is comprehensive and will address the issue the Cathaoirleach raised.
We were told that some of the OMCs had to get legal advice. Would that be monitored?

An issue we have seen relates to ownership and title. That does not now apply for the scheme as far as we are concerned, moving forward. We engaged with OMCs and it was a significant cost. Even with that cost, it is a difficult and long process without any guarantee of a successful outcome. I have no doubt legal costs tied to that process will now fall away.
The OMC may for different reasons, but for the purposes of this scheme, it will not require it.

Just on the scheme in question, we were not asking for support for legal advice. The specific issue was in the context of us having discussed the idea of a project manager previously. I think the idea was then taken up as being more like a foreman on site making sure things worked. It was highlighted to us in that instance that the insurer concerned was paying for the cost of remediation, but the relationship with the insurer was not unlike the relationship that will now exist with the State in respect of fire safety remediation. It was said that some of the challenges encountered included having to sign a contract with the building contractor. This obviously requires some level of knowledge or information, and I think it would suffice if the project manager has those skills.

With the indulgence of the Chair, there is a second piece here. It is the issue of the tenant liaison. It came up very prominently in the last hearing on this issue. Again, I think it would be worth hearing initial thoughts in this regard. It is a separate piece of work, particularly for those OMCs that do not necessarily have the skills within their board of directors or where there has been a history of conflict, division or tension, especially for very large schemes of perhaps 200 to 500 occupants. Something additional may be required there. I know a "Yes" can be given in response to it now, but I do think it is going to be something that will need to be considered in the course of the pre-legislative scrutiny of the wider scheme.

I thank Deputy Ó Broin. No other members are indicating. I thank everyone very much for coming in here again. I know they have had and will have a very busy schedule, so I thank the witnesses for their time to allow us to consider this proposed legislation. I propose we suspend briefly now to allow the witnesses to take their seats for our next session.

summary.i: Sitting suspended at 4.52 p.m. and resumed at 4.58 p.m.

speech.p: I welcome the following representatives from the Construction Defects Alliance, Mr. Pat Montague, co-ordinator, and Ms Fiona Dunkin, policy manager with Clúid. From the Not Our Fault group, I welcome Mr. Sam Doran. Before we start, I wish to explain to the witnesses some limitations of parliamentary privilege and the practice of the Houses as regards reference they may make to another person in their evidence. The evidence of witnesses physically present or who give evidence from within parliamentary precincts is protected, pursuant to both the Constitution and statute, by absolute privilege. Witnesses are reminded of the long-standing parliamentary practice that they should not criticise or make charges against any person or entity by name or in such a way as to make him, her or it identifiable or otherwise engage in speech that may be regarded as damaging to the good name of the person or entity. Therefore, if their statements are potentially defamatory in relation to an identifiable person or entity, they will be directed to discontinue their remarks. It is imperative that they comply with any such direction.
The opening statements have been circulated to members. I think we will take it that those opening statements have been read by members. Is it agreed that we will publish the statements? Agreed.
We will start now with our speaking rota. Based on the number of members here, we will go with ten minutes each. We will start with Deputy Séamus McGrath.

I thank the witnesses for coming in this afternoon. I want to start off with the opening statements in relation to the scale of the problem here. Mr. Montague's statement states, "In human terms, what that figure means in practice is that over 100,000 people are living in homes that do not have an acceptable level of fire safety with all of the worry and anxiety that this situation entails." That is a strong statement.

It was referenced somewhat in the earlier discussion. A figure of 44,000 was used. In fact, it is 54,000. In the working group report, 12,000 were estimated to have been fully remediated and 34,000 partially remediated, which leaves a cohort of 54,000 that basically have less than an acceptable level of fire safety. If you do the maths on that, you are talking about more than 100,000 people living in those units. They are the people who would fall prey if there were any incidents, God forbid, in those developments. That is the reality. I will give the Deputy a little snapshot. In one of the projects which has applied to the interim remediation scheme and has an extraordinarily high risk profile, in the last two weeks there have been fires in the foyer of the building. These were fires that were set off where bin bags were left there, and unfortunately some of the tenants, young people, set fire to the bin bags. That is exactly the sort of thing we are talking about.

The fire at Clarion Quay was caused by an overheating phone charger. That is what caused that fire. It does not take much. Mr. Doran will tell you about cigarettes thrown where rubbish is held on timber balconies. People leave flammable materials on it. The balconies themselves can have flammable timber. In a lot of cases, when they are flammable as in the case of Clarion, there is timber cladding attached to the windows and it is all linked in together. That is how the fire in Clarion went up. There is a high level of risk and it does not take much for that risk to become manifest.
Obviously within those 54,000 apartments, with over 100,000 residents, there are varying degrees of risk. Where would Mr. Montague quantify the high end in terms of a breakdown?
The answer is nobody knows.
We do not know.
Part of the reason that nobody knows is that, to some extent, there is a bit of smoke and mirrors - no pun intended. I heard some inappropriate words being used earlier on such as stumbling blocks.
As part of the interim scheme, was there to be a triaging of the most severe?

There has not been. Here is where things get messy. If the Deputy listens back to what the Department said on 18 November, it plays back to Deputy Hearne's points, both today and on 18 November. Basically, the Department is very clear - we had a vigorous discussion about this yesterday at the stakeholder forum - that legal responsibility under the fire services legislation and under the Multi-Unit Developments Act rests with the owners' management company. That is why the Department keeps on saying it is a demand-led scheme. The reality is that many of those owners' management companies are deliberately not looking. Why? The whole deck of cards collapses when they discover fire safety defects because-----
I made that point. Some of them are not facing up to it.

A lot of them are adopting a "Hear no evil, see no evil, speak no evil" approach. Once they open up works, they have to notify their insurers, and other things arise from that. What happens then is that their insurance goes from €36,000 a year to €197,000. We heard the insurance costs in Clarion Quay when we were there.
A lot of this is being buried, effectively.

Massively. We must recognise that owners' management companies are led by volunteers. They do not have expertise. We discussed this with the committee on 14 October when we looked at issues regarding the Multi-Unit Developments Act. We know that, frankly, a lot of owners' management companies are not well managed at all. Legally, yes, it is true that is where responsibility lies, but there has to be some role for the State to either mandate or require - it could be an amendment further down the road to the Multi-Unit Developments Act - that there be ongoing safety audits within this sector. Something like that has to be required unless there is some prodding by the State. In other words, if the State just sits back and it is up to companies to apply to the State, we are going to miss an awful lot of these fire safety issues. That laissez-faire approach is laden with challenges and difficulties. I do not think it is going to solve the problems. As I said, we had a vigorous discussion about this yesterday at the meeting.

Our starting point on this is the safe as houses report, which Deputy Ó Broin was involved in and was produced by a forebear of this committee, and the working group report, which was clear that the reason this issue came about in the first place was that the State has responsibility for the emergence of defects. It has responsibility because it did not oversee the building regulations effectively during the period between 1990 and early 2014. That is why this issue has emerged. It is not just down to shoddy workmanship. The builders were allowed to get away with shoddy workmanship because the State did not ensure compliance with its own building regulations. It is not sufficient simply to say it has regulations, it has regulated or legislated and it has done its bit. The State has to take a more hands-on role in encouraging the discovery of defects than it seems ready to take at the moment.

Instead of waiting for it to come to it. I accept that. I will ask about some of the specific points in relation to what we heard earlier. I think Mr. Doran and Ms Dunkin were here and Mr. Montague was listening. I raise the issue around common areas. Are they happy that this is satisfied now?
We have not seen the detail.
I know. Would Mr. Doran or Ms Dunkin like to speak?

It is a major step forward because it is not that they were not aware of it. When you get into it, you have to submit that you own the common areas. In our case, our building was built in 2003. Our common area was not signed over until 2009. There is six years and a gap in between it there. A lot of them are not aware. They have not even gone to check it out. It could be up to maybe 40% that will not have common areas. That is a great day for them today.
The Housing Agency effectively said that from now on they are able to proceed. That is important.
It will definitely bring forward more applications into the scheme because people have heard that this was an issue and have held back. It will definitely be a plus.
Before I move on, would Ms Dunkin like to comment?

On that point, looking at our own scheme with Clúid, we did a quick calculation on our top 100 OMCs. Approximately 68% of them have not had their common areas transferred over. Obviously none of those OMCs have applied for the scheme. The number in reality is going to be a lot greater than 25% to 30% because if the Deputy looked at the application process yesterday - maybe it has been changed today - it was clear that they were not eligible for this scheme.

People simply were not able to proceed. That has changed, according to today's testimony. On the issue of project management and what the witnesses heard earlier, it seems that there are steps in the right direction there. They are broadly welcome.

They are broadly welcome. Again, the devil is in the detail. We will have discussions. As people will be aware, since Caroline Timmons came into her role in the Department, we are now involved in the stakeholder forum.

There had been a stakeholder forum around defects remediation for some time but it involved just the Housing Agency and the Department. Now we are involved, which is a great step forward. We had a meeting yesterday. Let us see what emerges in the detail. There were some different emphases between the Department and the Housing Agency. The Department takes a more "suck it and see" approach and the Housing Agency is looking for a more belt and braces approach. We are absolutely clear and have said on two previous occasions that we need project managers. That needs to be there as a systemic part of the scheme.
My time is up but some of the other members might pick up on procurement and the frameworks in terms of what we heard today, in respect of the professionals but also the builders.

That is one of the questions I will follow up on. I want to focus on the detail. Over the last couple of weeks it is clear that the situation is actually quite fluid, which is positive because it means there is scope for improvements. I want to acknowledge that. We need to keep pressing for the detail we would like to see in those improvements. I have four questions which the witnesses can divide among themselves as they see fit. The first is about how we accelerate the process. The Housing Agency talked about how they think that, as a result of the learnings from the interim scheme, stage 2 with the competent professional and stage 3 with Dublin Fire Brigade could become much shorter. Mr. Doran had a full head of hair at the start of stage 2 and we can see the consequences of that. I would be interested to hear the witnesses' reactions to that and how we can ensure that those phases are as short as possible. That is the first one. The second one is to pick up on Deputy McGrath's point. It was interesting that the Housing Agency people were talking about a much more expanded definition of a project manager, not just a foreman but somebody who would have experience in some of those broader areas. I am inviting the witnesses to tell us what they need to see in that foreman's role. Likewise with the framework agreements, I invite them to fill in the detail they want to see. The third issue is the transitional mechanism. There has been quite a change. We seem to be inferred at an earlier stage that the bulk of the applications into the interim scheme would not be dealt with until the full scheme was up. The Housing Agency is now saying something substantively different. I want to invite the witnesses' response to that. Also, even where somebody in the interim scheme is getting the fire safety work, what is the best way to have them rolled into the new scheme? What would be seamless. Finally, we did not get to deal with the non-defects upgrades today but we will deal with it when the Department comes back. We are going to have to find a resolution to this. If there are fire safety issues that need addressed and the OMC does not have the money at that point to pay for that work, there will need to be some mechanism for the State to step in and pay it and then recoup it from the OMC at a later stage. I would like some detail on that, rather than the general principles. That will help us when we are with the Department and ultimately doing our prelegislative scrutiny report next year.
Mr. Doran might answer on the procurement as he has dealt with it.

On the procurement thing, in our place we had done a tender process and gone all the way to drawing down the money. When we were drawing down the money, they came to the conclusion that they could not give us the money because it was more than 50% so it had to be on public procurement. That put us right back to the start all over again. It was a lengthy thing with procurement. It is complicated, it takes a lot of time and it is slow getting through it. When you get to picking and moving on, it takes a lot of time. On the project manager role, that really came from the competent professionals. They were architects, engineers or surveyors but they did not want to communicate with the OMC. They will go in and survey the building and that is as far as their job goes. We had gone through three competent professionals until we got to the company we have at the moment. They were fairly hands on, explained everything to us and encouraged us to be there every day when they were doing the opening of works to explain what the problems were. We got to learn a lot. That is where the project manager comes in. The competent professional does not way to talk to lay people so we need somebody to bridge the gap there and go back to them to make sure they get what they need, and then the process can move on. The lack of engagement by the competent professional was holding up the process.

I will come back to that but I want to come to the procurement piece. I listened with interest when Mr. O'Halloran was talking about that earlier and mentioned a 12 to 18-month period. To be frank, nobody has got through in 12 months. It is 18 months or so at the moment. Having spoken to the Housing Agency, the view is that with a fair wind, leaving aside the new elements, under the current process it would take about 13 to 14 months. I think with the additional things we are still talking about a nine or ten-month process. One of the things we have to do is around the issue of fire alarms. I was really struck by Mr. Dennis Keeley's comments when he was in here on 18 November, that fire alarms are the key element of any fire safety strategy. We mentioned that in our opening statement. I think we need to look at decoupling the provision of fire alarms from the procurement morass. I remember engaging with a former CEO of the Housing Agency. Their view was that they would basically go in like a buzz saw through all those 54,000 or whatever, to put in fire alarms and do it over a period of two or three years. We need to look at a much more ambitious, fast-moving approach to fire alarm installation. That might involve it being done directly by the Housing Agency. For me, that is the biggest single thing that needs to be done in the first instance.

That comes back to the issue of the interim scheme. There is unfortunately a misunderstanding at times, and again we had a vigorous debate about this yesterday. The interim scheme is not interim in terms of time. It is about putting in place the interim fire safety measures as recommended in recommendation No. 5 of the working group report, and as set out in section 8 of the code of practice. It is not about being interim and then to be wrapped up into the full scheme. We made it very clear that there needs to be a separate thread for the interim scheme within the statutory scheme. The number one priority has to be to ensure that those 54,000 homes are all brought up to an acceptable level of safety as quickly as possible. The idea of doing all the rest of the stuff while we are there seems nuts to me. We have made that very clear. We have to focus on getting that done first, hence the idea of decoupling the installation of fire alarms from the procurement piece and looking at other ways of doing that. It is really crucial and would bring the level up much more quickly than we are able to do at the moment. The way it is currently being done in respect of provision of fire alarms is way too slow, given the level of risk that exists.

I totally agree with Mr. Montague on that. It needs to be decoupled. Procurement is going to take time and we all accept that. If we can find ways to circumvent it, great, but we need to deal with the very urgent items which we mentioned at the last discussion. If we are taking that approach, which would be fantastic, we do not necessarily have a full view of the risk ratings within the actual applicants so far for the interim remediation scheme. The application process is very light-touch, which is positive and was done intentionally to allow people to move through applying to the scheme on an initial basis before moving on to the more complex areas around the scheme itself.

There is a yes or no question whether a fire safety risk assessment has been undertaken. If you click "No", you will still be taken through to the application process. We do not necessarily have a view of the risk. There may be a view that height would be looked at first but it is just to make that point that we do not necessarily have an understanding of which we would go through or where would we put the smoke alarms in the fire detection first if we were to take that approach.

To follow up on the piece about protecting the interim measures scheme, we have come to a view after the discussions we have had that it may be prudent to actually include a specific section in the legislation in relation to interim remediation scheme. Folding it in and that it all becomes the one thing would be a grave error. We have to focus on bringing everybody up to standard. Bringing those 54,000 units up and folding them in has to be the priority. The Department is now aware of our view on that. We had a full discussion about it yesterday. I am just saying it here. It probably is required to have a specific section in the legislation regarding the interim remediation scheme. Remembering what the then Minister, Deputy O'Brien, said when it was launched, it is about providing people with an acceptable level of safety while they are awaiting full remediation. That is the biggest need and the biggest challenge we have at the moment.

I do not have any questions but I wanted to make a couple of observations. It has been a great listening exercise for me and I had the opportunity to listen to the previous contributions, even when I was not here. The witnesses have made very sensible and common-sense suggestions, first and foremost regarding the fire alarms. Prevention is always key. People have lived with enough stress and fear without taking this on board and adopting it very quickly. Is there something to be considered, even outside of a legislative approach, to guarantee that this could be a speedier process and maybe find a way that the Housing Agency can, in the interim adopt a measure so that it does not have to wait for the passage of legislation?

On the point as regards nudging people along in those management agencies to allow them to come forward. They are not agencies but I am lost for words today. I get a hint from what the witnesses were saying that they are nearly too afraid to scratch the surface in case it opens a Pandora's box of items that have perhaps nothing to do with the other issues on hand. Then, we come into the complications of insurance. Also there, I refer to some engagement while we wait for the passage of legislation to encourage them to move quicker on this. As they are quick to say, this is demand-led. It would be beneficial for everybody concerned because then we will get a quicker view of the whole picture.
