One of the things that had been discussed previously was that, when the interim remediation scheme was launched, two years ago next week, it was agreed that there would be a proactive information campaign run by the Department. We are not talking about letters but about a campaign in social, local and national media. A budget was allocated for it. I think that is necessary. To be fair, the reason it was held back at that time, and we heard it already, was because we hit the buffers in terms of local authority fire services resourcing, which was why we then pivoted towards just working with four pathfinders. Now that we are, in a sense, putting the proper systems in place, it strikes me that we are again coming back to the State acting not so much as a passive agent and saying the responsibility is on OMCs and it is demand-led. That is part of the proactive approach. I know Mr. O'Halloran mentioned that the Housing Agency had been doing MUDs seminars and all the rest of it. That is fine but the people who are going to that are people who are in the know. The reality is, the vast majority of owners' management companies have no connection with the Housing Agency and no connection with the State. We do not even have a database. There are thousands of them. There are loads of them out there living in blissful ignorance or, obviously less than blissful ignorance. The problem is that it is the people living in those complexes who would bear the brunt if something were to happen. We have made it clear that we have a responsibility as a society to go beyond simply saying we put the scheme and the regulations in place and it is up to the owners to come to us. The State has to be way more proactive, given its responsibility for the creation of this mess in the first place.

On that, just thinking out loud, there could be a voucher system with the local authorities, where, once it is identified that theirs is a defective apartment, people simply go in, get their voucher and go to a local supplier, or the authority might have a list of trusted suppliers who would come and fit these alarms systems. These costs could then be recouped later on.

One of the issues is that what we are looking to do is ensure the standard is there. It is not just fire alarms. We are looking at stuff like the decibel levels of bell heads. One of the big challenges at the moment is that the noise of the alarm system is loud enough so that if somebody is asleep in bed, it will wake them up. That was one of the problems that was highlighted when we were in Clarion Quay. They did not have that. It was just pure luck. What actually happened was the person in whose apartment the fire started went around, after the alarm went off, and knocked on people's doors to get them out because some people had slept right through the alarm. Why? The noise was not loud enough to wake them. This was happening in the wee hours of the morning. The fire started after midnight. I think what the Deputy is saying is we need to find a way, whatever way it is, of quickly bringing up the standard of the fire alarms. I am not sure everybody is sufficiently seized of the urgency of that.
I am not for one minute suggesting people get a voucher, go into the nearest shop, buy any old alarm and just install it yourself. It has to be of the right level, it has-----
Absolutely.
-----to be functioning and be approved. However, having to wait to insert this into legislation is far too slow in my mind.
It is.

I would hate to think a fire would start and rampage through a building. I read something there about the golden hour. We do not have that luxury in these buildings. Surely there is a practical measure that we can put in place within a matter of weeks or months.

One of the other challenges in that regard is the issue about owners' management companies being able to access people's apartments in order to do that. The owners' management company has responsibility for the common areas. There are often challenges in accessing apartments themselves to carry out works. That is something we would need to look at in providing owners' management companies with the wherewithal to do that. It is not just about the sanctity of people's apartments because of the nature of apartment living. What happened in Clarion Quay is that a fire started in one person's apartment and spread to everybody else's. It cannot be contained within one place. The notion that somehow I can say "you are not coming into my place to check on the alarms", owners' management companies need to be able to go in and ensure this. It is a safety issue not for one person in their apartment but for everybody living in that block and, at the moment, there are challenges around that.

In our own existence, we were one of the first to be identified with fire defects and we had the threats such as being put out of our homes. We had engaged with Dennis Keeley on that. What we had to do was put in a fire alarm ourselves, which cost €394,000.

We had to hit all the members to pay for it. As we said, as regards decibels, it has to be brought up to 75 dB. Most of the apartments only have a sounder in the hall, however. When the bedroom doors are closed, they do not hear it. If they have drunk alcohol, especially after a football match – I had one such incident a couple of weeks ago - they fall asleep and do not hear it. That happened in another development. We put that in to provide early warning. We then put in 156 fire extinguishers, which cost another €16,000. We also had to service our automatic opening vents, AOVs, and the whole lot.

The OMC needs to be active. Putting in a fire alarm is grand but if a fire alarm activates, someone might decide they are not going out and may turn off the panel and remove the head on the ceiling instead. If they do not put it back up the next day and then they go on holidays for two weeks, there is no early warning in that apartment. That is where a fire really gets going. In our place, I walk our building and sign off on it every day. This is where the OMC has to take some responsibility that it is checking the fire panels. In our case, if someone removes a fire head, we will hit them with a €200 fine. If it is not paid within 28 days, we take their parking in the car park. We enforce it. We have had nine panels handed over to the builder in nine different blocks and not one of them had a yellow light on because of the enforcement we do. It is easy putting in the fire alarm. It is about the maintenance and policing of it and making sure people do not interfere with it. If that is done, it provides an early warning and is effective. People getting an early warning is the most important part of the building. They should have 60 minutes to get out but due to the defects, they do not have 60 minutes so every minute is important. That is the kind of money that you are talking about for fire alarms. We are a big building with 232 units, so it depends on the size. It is the most important thing.

Sorry, I had to go to another meeting. I echo what was said earlier. I have a real concern that we are not identifying, and have not identified, buildings at risk. We do not know. As mentioned, it is a demand-led scheme and there are potentially thousands of people living in buildings that are unsafe that we do not know about. No one seems to be proactively going out to try to find that out.

No, there is not. To be clear, it is correct to say that under the fire services legislation and the Multi-Unit Developments Act 2011, the legal responsibility rests with the directors of the owners' management companies. That is correct. I am not sure that will actually do the job, however.
It is more than a legal responsibility. The State has a responsibility to its citizens in terms of their well-being and health.
Absolutely.
I just do not understand how the Department can say it does not know or have any sense of the number of potentially unsafe buildings.

Mr. Montague mentioned earlier that an information campaign is vital. The welcome change and legal advice around the common area transfer are great. We need to have an information campaign now, from today, to let those people and OMCs know, which did not apply last week because they knew they were not eligible for it, that they are now eligible. As I said, that is 68% of our OMCs within Clúid. That increases the number massively.
Could the fire services be required to carry out assessments of these buildings? Could they be given the resources and time to do that, given that we know this is a problem?

If they go out and are aware of an issue, they will have to empty the building. They did that years ago and it proved very costly. I do not think they want to revisit that. That is the reason we are being told the onus is on the OMCs.
The State has powers in this regard. The dangerous buildings and dangerous places legislation empowers-----
The State is adopting a we-do-not-want-to-know approach because of the consequences if it finds out. Of course, no one wants to put people out of their homes.

There are 1,000 people in our building. We got all those threats at the start that we were going to be put out if we did not pay up, but the people could not pay up. We lost our insurance for ten days but then we got it back, but for mad money. We were going to lose our mortgages. They were going to be called in because we did not have insurance. People were totally stressed out. Then it quietened down. We did something to bring it up to a level. We policed our building and did what we could to stay safe and it did not proceed.

This goes hand in glove with the issues around the Multi-Units Developments Act because the State does not have a list of all the OMCs in the country. Such a list does not exist. Therefore, it cannot communicate with all of them directly to inform them of a scheme, their responsibilities and all the rest of it. That is why we are talking more generally about a media campaign. It will still be hit or miss but it is better than what is there at the moment.

The Deputy is right; there is nothing being done proactively. Even when it comes to the assessment process, it is all desk-bound, as is the issuing of fire certificates, for instance. It was said earlier that these buildings have fire certificates but, frankly, the fire certificates are not worth a tuppenny damn. They are based on whether these buildings were built in accordance with the original plans and designs. The reason they are defective is that they were not. You cannot rely on those fire certificates. They are meaningless. The Deputy is right that there is a sort of passive approach. If we are going to address this, there needs to be a more proactive approach, one where the State is acting like the good, proactive citizen, as distinct from a passive approach and sitting back, which largely has been the approach.

To be clear, this is a big an improvement on what existed before because the approach before 2020 was basically to say, “Don't knock on our door, we don't want to talk to you. We're not interested. Go and fix it yourselves. It has nothing to do with us.” That at least has changed. To be fair, this committee is due huge credit because there is now cross-party consensus that this needs to be tackled, which is why we are discussing the legislation. Things have changed but this committee has an opportunity to advance that even further with the report it writes around this legislation. That piece about the State's role is an important one.

We do it well when it comes to food safety. The Food Safety Authority issues warnings around salmonella and other products. We do not know who has bought those products, similar to OMCs. We do not know where the OMCs necessarily are or where the defects are. That is why a wide-ranging campaign is absolutely vital.
In our experience, the best thing that can be done is to get fire alarms into all of these buildings as quickly as possible.
That is crucial.

One thing I found important in our development was that when fire defects are identified, everyone must be notified. When the people who lived in our building knew the defects, they knew what to watch out for and what not to do. For example, if someone were to have a barbeque in Park West at the moment, my phone would be hopping straight away with people informing me that they have seen someone entering the building with a gas cylinder or barbeque. Before the individual would ever get to light the barbeque, residents would be onto me to go and sort it out. The residents police the building strongly because they are aware there is danger. By not investigating or finding out, they are not protecting their own people. They need to know what the defects are. They need to know what the consequences of certain things are. Then they can police it themselves. We have so many buildings with defects and there is nowhere to move the people to.
The State should know, at minimum.
It should know. Even the people living there should know they are living with danger so they are aware of it.
It is not going to be fixed overnight. It is going to take time.

However, the fire alarms piece can be done relatively quickly. It is relatively low cost too, particularly if you are doing it at scale. That is something that can be done that would make a massive difference to those 100,000-plus people living in those units.

Fire alarms could be done in days if they are wireless. They do not have to be wired. It is only a matter of fitting modules. You are not trying to run cables. If the will was there to do it within a couple of months, you could have fire alarms into all these places.

Mr. Montague was being very kind talking about the expertise in the committee. Let us be honest. Listening to what he was talking about in relation to Priory Hall and some of the other issues, we have come an incredibly long way. The main reason that has happened is because of the people who have lived in those complexes who have been fighting very hard to seek an alternative to the courts declaring somewhere has to be shut down and where the fire certificate was the responsibility of the local authority or Dublin Fire Brigade and then the local authority having to step in in some way. That is all down to the people who lived in the complexes and the expertise there. It is also a bit of an exception. Deputy Ó Broin talked about the position being fluid. The fact that we will have pre-legislative scrutiny and there is so much agreement between the Department and those immediately impacted points to the very active and ongoing conversation that is happening with the witnesses on one side and the Department on the other. Even the changes confirmed earlier, which are very welcome, about the common areas, the project management assistance, the movement of the framework, for example, the alternative for procurement, even in the past couple of months or maybe weeks, show the movement we have had. An awful lot has happened. We deal with pre-legislative scrutiny all the time. There are many Bills we would be not be as informed about and equally so the Department. It is because of the work that has been done. It is worth underscoring that.

The pre-legislative scrutiny report is an opportunity for us to shape legislation. There are things that would be appropriate for the legislation and things that will be appropriate for the scheme. It will be really important. I am looking at the opening statement and there is a mix. In tabular form or an index, it might be worth identifying in the report those which are specific to the legislation and that the witnesses feel are important for it and those that might be more for the operation of the scheme, supports and so on. The reason is that I do not want to have to suggest amendments. The amending Stage should be really simple. We should not have many amendments. It would be good to point out to the Department specific things that the witnesses want in the legislation early on rather than what they are happy to accept in operational terms.

In our previous submission, we went through this head by head and set out changes that we were looking for in each head. The only addition to that is the requirement for a specific section in relation to the interim remediation scheme. That is because it is patently clear to us now that there is a fundamental misunderstanding or there has been one. I hope that after yesterday it may be changing. To be fair, the Department representatives did say they would take away what we had to say which is testament to the Deputy’s earlier point that we now have a process. To be fair, we are now part of the stakeholder forum. In the past I had observed it was a case of a stakeholder forum but where were the stakeholders? Why were we not at the table? To be fair to Caroline Timmins, she brought us in straight away so I give her huge credit for that. For me, that is the single biggest thing.

There has been a fundamental misunderstanding about the nature of the interim scheme. It is not interim, in that it is there to transition into the full scheme. It is interim because it addresses the immediate measures set out in the working group report and in the fire safety code of practice. Those interim measures are the number 1 priority that need to be addressed. Those interim measures are about providing people with an acceptable level of safety so they can continue living in their homes while they are awaiting full remediation. That has to be enshrined in the legislation so we do not end up with a dog’s dinner of a situation where they talked about the thing folding in. The problem is that if it folds in, we could end up where people with an urgent need end up competing with people who might have water ingress issues. Those are very difficult and intractable but we have to prioritise life safety first. That comes back to the fire alarm stuff. That needs to be done but those are outside matters to do with the scheme or whatever. However, from our point of view, in addition to what we put in the first one-----
The specific thing we should be referencing from a legislative perspective is the interim scheme.
Absolutely.
Did it say it was going to be enacted in that way?

What it said was more in terms of looking at how it was going to be integrated. The only provision at the moment that relates to the interim scheme is what are called transitional arrangements and that is basically about phasing it out. What we are saying is that the interim scheme does not close until everybody has an acceptable level of safety.
Is it worth identifying timelines in the legislation or specific targets? Is that something Mr. Montague would like to see?
What it identifies is the stuff that is in the code of practice which are the type of measures which might identify priority works for the scheme.

I am sorry to rush Mr. Montague but we have such limited time. The second area is the Multi-Units Developments Act, and he knows my view on that from last time, and the regulator. The point was made earlier that if we had a regulator and a mandatory list of OMCs, it would be very easy to inform every OMC of its legal obligation because they would all be regulated and they would all have registered contacts and we would be able to have an evidence trail of having informed them of their legal obligations. The social media campaigns and all of that are really important but if you have a proper regulator and a proper register you do not need some of that.
Correct.

Mr. Montague will have heard the comment I put to the Department. We have been nice to them in the first half so let us be more critical of them in the second half of the conversation. I am not happy with the response from the Department in regard to the transition from justice. I have not had any update from the Department of justice. I wonder have the witnesses.

Deputy Roderic O’Gorman put down a parliamentary question on 27 November. The reply came back that there is basically a one-size-fits-all piece of legislation for criminal and civil issues - I cannot remember the name-----
Like an omnibus Bill.

An omnibus Bill. It has gone through pre-legislative scrutiny. I think the report was issued by the justice committee on 13 November. There is a provision in that to address the Mulcreevy case issues. However, that has just gone through pre-legislative scrutiny and obviously it still has to go through the full process. The fact it is added in with a lot of other stuff in an omnibus piece of legislation means that being realistic, I do not see it getting passed until mid-year next year. That means we are towards the back end of next year before any regulatory work can begin. My understanding is, and it is a fair position, that the Department has not allocated any resources to the Housing Agency for 2026 to do any regulatory work because it does not have jurisdiction for it. I hope the Department will come back with a Supplementary Estimate for that because the amount of money involved is very small. It is about people. Unfortunately, however, the time of year means we will be talking about 2027 before any effective regulation begins.

Even though it is not related to the legislation before us, we need to reference this in our pre-legislative scrutiny report. If you were the Comptroller and Auditor General and you were being really cautious, you would be saying the remediation scheme should not proceed without that regulation being in place. That is the difficulty. Are there any protections we could put into this legislation that would pre-empt the work that would be done in a full review?

We need to look somewhere, whether it is this Bill or the MUD Bill, but it is probably this one. We certainly need to look at strengthening OMCs' ability to access people's apartments. There are provisions in relation to that but they need to be reviewed to make sure they are watertight, for instance, with things like fire alarm upgrades or smoke detectors or whatever. I was talking to somebody in an OMC today who was saying they were trying to put proper smoke detectors into an apartment and the owner would not let them in. They just could not get in. This is an issue not just for that person but for everybody living in that building, so there is an issue about empowering OMCs so they can do the works that are necessary to protect people's safety. That needs to be enshrined in this legislation.
That is useful. I thank Mr. Montague.

I have a couple of questions. There was a term used, which was an acceptable level of safety when it comes to fire alarms. There should not be an acceptable level of safety but a high level when it comes to that. Mr. Doran mentioned going from €36,000 for insurance to-----
I assume that is common.
It is. I was informed last week RSA has reviewed the insurance on two other developments because of the fire defects not moving on.
We had a similar experience in Clúid with massive leaps in insurance costs.
Are insurance companies using it as an opportunity?

I would not think so. I think they are calculating the risks and they are saying there is a danger there. Our building is valued at €97 million, overall, so that is the risk. It is a huge risk taken on.

In some cases what happens is the insurance companies, when it comes to renewal time, are saying - especially about the issue around delays - people were told there was a scheme or people had applied for a scheme, but the work still has not been done. They are giving people a year to get works done or they will withdraw cover. Mr. Doran mentioned that happened in his place. He lost cover for about ten days.

We lost cover. The company had been warning it was going to withdraw cover but the management agent in place at the time had not informed us of it. It came up to the deadline of the end of February and the company pulled the cover. We had to search around for ten days. We ended up going with a broker here who went to a broker in England and that broker got insurance from Germany for us, so we are insured with a German company. It is the only way we can get insurance put on the building.

I noted there was a question on insurance asked of Caroline Timmins earlier. She referenced the fact the former Minister, Deputy O'Brien, had discussions with the insurance company but our conversations with him went further than just that piece, which was also about the fact the increased costs to OMCs and then to owners as a result of insurance hikes are something owners should be able to get back because they are directly related to the defects. To be fair to the former Minister, he indicated he would consider that and look at it. It is something that needs to become part of the scheme in the form or retrospective payments and reimbursement as those costs are a direct result of the defects and are not in any way the fault of the owners but it is the owners who are having to foot the bill.

He did say there would be insurance support. I went into his office when we were losing the insurance. He asked me for a copy of our policy and said he would see what he could do. When we were losing the insurance we had a corporate landlord and they threatened us with a solicitor's letter that they were taking us to the High Court for not having insurance. They said their investors felt nervous we did not have insurance so they were looking to take us to court to wind it up. When I got insurance they came back and said we had stolen their insurance. I asked how and they said they were working on it. I had to go back to the former Minister and say did I not speak to him ten days ago and say I was working on this insurance. I do not know where they were going with it but they served me with solicitors' letters for their investors. It was not about the people in the building; it was that their investors were nervous. Insurance was a headache. The former Minister said to me not to worry and there would be insurance support.
That is important.

That is what he told me. How do you go from €36,000 to €19,000? The Minister, Deputy Carroll MacNeill, was the Minister of State with responsibility for insurance at that time and she came out to us and tried to get insurance for us to assist us in any way she could. The two of them were working on it at the time.
All right. I thank Mr. Doran. We have five minutes and I will let members who indicate back in. I call Deputy Ó Broin.

I will make a few quick observations and if people want to respond, that is fine. Even if the legislation to facilitate the transfer, like the MUD Bill, etc., were to happen tomorrow we need to be a bit realistic here. The Government will set up a working group, there will be a public consultation and it will be several years before there are any recommendations. In the best-case scenario nothing will be happening on actual reform of the Multi-Unit Developments Acts, the creation of an OMC regulator and all the things we agree are needed before this scheme opens. An issue Deputy McAuliffe rightly raised at a previous meeting is handing over tens of million of euro to unregulated bodies. There is a solution to that, which is not handing over tens of million of euro to unregulated bodies but having framework agreements through the Housing Agency so the agency enters into the contracts, as has happened through the Pyrite Resolution Board. Everything is done in consultation with, and with the agreement of, the OMC. There is therefore a mechanism that could be introduced or at least should be explored in this legislation either for all OMCs or for OMCs where there are significant governance challenges, given the scale of money involved. I offer that by way of observation.

There are two things that are changing. If we take the view as a committee when we do our deliberations on the pre-legislative scrutiny that the interim works must be done first and that becomes the position, that is very different from where we were when we were initially discussing the general scheme. This is because the general scheme has a transitional provision just to roll the interim scheme into the overall scheme, so it is almost like a scheme that has two parts. Right across the State all the interim works would have to be done first and then we would move on to the other works. We just need to think that through. I am not against the proposition because it makes eminent sense but it is a big shift from what is in the general scheme. It is also a big shift in terms of cost because the €100 million Caroline Timmins mentioned earlier is not €100 million for this scheme but €100 million for all defects, namely, Leinster pyrite, defective blocks, interim, retrospective and new schemes. It will be more money than we had in previous years but if we prioritise certain categories of work, they are the ones that have to get funded.

Likewise, we are introducing - and I am not opposed to it at all - not just retrospective cost in terms of remediation works but other costs that were incurred by OMCs as a consequence of defects. Obviously insurance is one but there is, for example, an ancillary grant provision in the defective concrete block scheme that covers the cost of storage and accommodation during works. When we were in the scheme in the docklands, families had to move out for two years-----
€4,500 a month.

Their insurance policy paid for a portion of that but only a portion. All I want to do is highlight that if we are now moving towards making the case for those as a committee, which we will obviously discuss in private session, we need to be very clear that means we are talking not just about retrospective payment of remediation costs but also about ancillary grants, some of which would be retrospective, for costs incurred as a consequence of defects existing. None of those things are in this scheme and they need to be thought through.

On the issue of fire alarms, and Mr. Montague, Ms Dunkin or Mr. Doran should correct me if I am wrong, not all fire alarm systems are defective. That begs a question which we are going to have to grapple with in the pre-legislative scrutiny report. There will be fire alarm systems that were defectively installed which will therefore be covered by the interim scheme and-or the wider scheme. There will also be a lot which are not defective but will need upgrading or to be replaced but the OMC does not have the money. I am not arguing that the State should pay for those. If the witnesses want to make that case, that is fine, but I am arguing that those works are going to have to be done. On whether the State pays for them up front and places a 0% interest rate charge on the OMC to be repaid over time, without that the fire service is not going to sign off on that bit of stage three of the process. We have raised it with the Department but it has not responded. Ultimately, that is a political decision; it is not a Civil Service decision. We cannot have a situation where there are some fire safety defects, for example, like a fire escape, and there are maintenance issues around fire alarms, and the works cannot proceed because the OMC does not have the money to upgrade the fire systems.

As a case in point, we had a meeting this morning and one of the people at it was talking about how in their complex, they had done the defects remediation work themselves. They want to bring their alarm system up to date but they have had to put that on hold because they used their sinking fund towards the remediation costs as well as imposing a levy of about €15,000 or €16,000 per owner. They have nothing left in the tank.
That is less of a concern to me, so long as they are retrospectively reimbursed.
That is the point but they cannot proceed with the other stuff until they get the money back.
My point is a different one. At least they had a sinking fund and they were able to dip into it to fix some urgent stuff.
Correct.

Where an OMC does not have a sinking fund and does not have the wherewithal to bring its fire alarm system up to standard, we are going to have a problem. On some of the pathfinder projects, there were some issues that were not originally seen as defects but then on further inspection, it was discovered that they were defective. On some of these things like the lighting systems and fire alarms, there are going to be a lot of poor maintenance cases.
Absolutely.

The committee would be on stronger ground not if we are asking for the State to pay for that but to pay for it, in the first instance, and to then have a mechanism to recoup it over time, so long as it is on a 0% interest basis, for example.

I do not think that we would have a problem with that because the principle has been agreed that issues to do with the lack of maintenance by the owners' management company is not a defect. To be fair, in the cases the Deputy talked about, some of the pathfinders were quite generous in terms of their interpretations of what was a defect and what was not. The amount of money involved in each case was very small. The Deputy is right. Some of the OMCs would be challenged to have the money to do that. It would be a lost opportunity not to do it, when we are doing other stuff as it would ensure that people have that protection.

It is important to understand that it is more fundamental than that. Dublin Fire Brigade is not going to sign off on its portion of stage three unless it is assured that all of those works are done, whether they are defects are not.
Absolutely.

We will therefore not be able to proceed to stage four without a fix for that. I am highlighting it because, from the sounds of it, the Department has removed the ownership of common areas from the criteria, which is great.
It is brilliant.
Equally, we have to find a fix for the maintenance upgrades, where the OMC does not have the wherewithal.
I just want to quickly add something.
We have gone over time.

The OMCs cannot get finance. The banks will not lend to them because they have no assets to secure a loan against. The Deputy referred to a 0% loan. That would be a way out of it for them because they cannot borrow money. The only thing they can do is go back and hit people with levies again. Levies do not work. Even Leo Varadkar paid a levy. He told me that a third paid, a third would not and a third could not, so the works could not be carried out on his building either. What do they do then? They put levies on people and then take legal action against them. We know of people around the country where levies were imposed on them regarding fire works. They have been before the courts and their credit rating is now gone and they are destroyed. Ruthless management agents then moved the levy onto the management fee, so that they could charge more interest at 20%. These people are now stuck in limbo because they cannot do anything. If there was a mechanism where management companies could apply to the State for a 0% loan, I think they would be only too delighted to do that and to pay it back. It is a good idea.

I thank Mr. Doran, Ms Dunkin and Mr. Montague for coming in, not just today, but on numerous occasions. We thank them for their work and advocacy as they continue to highlight this issue that affects 54,000 apartments. It is important to acknowledge Caroline Timmins from the Department. We plan to have another discussion with representatives from the Department. We originally had it pencilled in for next Tuesday but we might have to move it to Thursday as it clashes with other committee and Seanad commitments. I think the defective block scheme is in the Seanad. I thank the witnesses. We will work on a report. I would like to see us agree on a report prior to Christmas.

debateSection.summary: The joint committee adjourned at 6:08 p.m. until 3 p.m. on Tuesday, 9 December 2025.
